subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Indeed. ... Not so much widely distributed as highly prestigious in the U.K. It would now be called Conservative RP . ... QS would be inadequate for
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> 1. That Kingsley Read was intelligent and well informed thus, at least
> to him if not me, the examples in QM are consistent.

Indeed.

> 2. That Read was using a accent widely distributed in the middle
> 20th century.

Not so much "widely distributed" as "highly prestigious in the U.K."
It would now be called "Conservative RP".

> Personally I will greatly enjoy a detailed conversation about the
> precise sound or set of sounds of each letter. Indeed the result of
> such a study might have mind boggling benefits: for example it might
> allow us to transcribe Milton or Shakespeare et al into the original
> accent easily approached by anyone knowing QS.

QS would be inadequate for the purpose: for example, it does not have
a letter for the /E:/ used in Shakespeare's day for "meat", as distinct
from /E/ ("met"), /e/ ("mate"), and /i/ ("meet").

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
If a soldier is asked why he kills people who have done him no harm, or a
terrorist why he kills innocent people with his bombs, they can always
reply that war has been declared, and there are no innocent people in an
enemy country in wartime. The answer is psychotic, but it is the answer
that humanity has given to every act of aggression in history. --Northrop Frye
